title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #701: Chvátal's Conjecture**

Let F be a hereditary family (closed under subsets).

**Conjecture:** There exists x such that for all intersecting F' ⊆ F:
|F'| ≤ |{A ∈ F : x ∈ A}|

**Status:** OPEN

**Partial results:** Chvátal 1974, Sterboul 1974, Frankl-Kupavskii 2023
mathContext: This generalizes Erdős-Ko-Rado to hereditary families. The conjecture says stars achieve the maximum intersecting subfamily size.

title: Hereditary Family
content:
**IsHereditary F:** B ⊆ A ∈ F implies B ∈ F.

Also called downsets, ideals, or independence systems. These are families closed under taking subsets.

title: Power Set Example
content:
**powerset_hereditary:** The power set P(X) is hereditary.

This is the prototypical example - if A ⊆ X and B ⊆ A, then B ⊆ X.

title: Bounded Cardinality Example
content:
**bounded_card_hereditary:** {A : |A| ≤ k} is hereditary.

Subsets of small sets are small. This is the independence system of a uniform matroid.

title: Intersecting Family
content:
**IsIntersecting F:** For all A, B ∈ F: (A ∩ B).Nonempty.

Every two sets in the family have non-empty intersection. This is the key structural constraint in extremal set theory.

title: Star Definition
content:
**Star F x:** {A ∈ F : x ∈ A}

The star at x is the subfamily of all sets containing x. Stars are the conjectured maximizers for intersecting subfamilies.

title: Stars are Intersecting
content:
**star_intersecting:** Star F x is intersecting.

All sets in a star contain x, so any two sets intersect at least at x. This makes stars natural candidates for maximum intersecting subfamilies.

title: Chvátal's Conjecture
content:
**ChvatalConjecture F:** IsHereditary F →
∃ x, ∀ intersecting F' ⊆ F: |F'| ≤ |Star F x|

The maximum size of an intersecting subfamily equals the size of some star. This is the main open problem.

title: Open Status
content:
**chvatal_conjecture_open:**

Axiom recording that the conjecture is unresolved in full generality.

The conjecture has been open since 1974 despite significant partial progress.
mathContext: Axiomatizing an open conjecture allows formal reasoning about its consequences.

title: Sterboul's Conditions
content:
**SterboulConditions, sterboul_1974:**

Chvátal's conjecture holds when:
1. All maximal sets have equal size
2. Pairwise intersections have size ≤ 1
3. At least two maximal sets intersect

These conditions capture certain 'regular' hereditary families.
mathContext: Sterboul's result covers matroids and similar structures with uniform maximal sets.

title: Frankl-Kupavskii 2023
content:
**frankl_kupavskii_2023:**

Chvátal's conjecture holds for families with covering number 2.

The covering number τ(F) is the minimum number of elements hitting all sets. This 2023 result is significant recent progress.
mathContext: Published in Discrete Mathematics (2023). Covering number 2 is a strong but natural condition.

title: Borg's Weighted Version
content:
**WeightedChvatalConjecture:**

Generalizes the conjecture to weighted families:
∑_{A ∈ F'} w(A) ≤ ∑_{A ∈ Star(F,x)} w(A)

Borg (2011) proved this under additional assumptions.

title: EKR Connection
content:
**Erdős-Ko-Rado Context:**

EKR bounds intersecting families in uniform hypergraphs:
max |F'| = C(n-1, k-1) for k-uniform families on [n].

Chvátal's conjecture generalizes this to hereditary families, where uniform families are NOT directly applicable.
mathContext: EKR is for uniform families, which aren't hereditary (subsets of k-sets have smaller cardinality).

title: Uniform Not Hereditary
content:
**uniform_not_hereditary:**

For k ≥ 2, the family of all k-subsets is NOT hereditary.

Proof: A k-set has (k-1)-subsets, which aren't in the k-uniform family.

This explains why Chvátal's conjecture is distinct from EKR.

title: Summary Theorem
content:
**erdos_701_summary:**

Combines the main conjecture statement with partial results.

**Status:** OPEN since 1974.

**Why it's hard:** Need a SINGLE x that works for ALL intersecting subfamilies simultaneously. Local arguments fail.
